ost_step.1: Notice that some angles add up to certain special angles or complementary pairs like sine double angle formulas use ($\sin^2 x= \frac {1-\cos 2x} 2$). For example,\begin{align*} & \sin\left(\theta+\frac {\pi}  2\right)=\cos \theta\\& \sin\left(\theta-\frac {\pi}  2\right)=-\cos \theta \\& \sin(\pi -\theta)=\sin (\theta)\\&\end{align*}In particular, notice how$$\sin 20^\circ =\sin (80^\circ -60^\circ ) =\sin 80^\circ \cos 60^\circ-\sin 60^\circ\cos 80^\circ $$and $$\sin 100^\circ =\sin (120^\circ - 20^\circ ) =\sin 120^\circ \cos 20^\circ-\sin 20^\circ\cos 120^\circ.$$Now substitute into our original expression:\begin{align*}\sin 20^\circ \sin 40^\circ \sin 60^\circ \sin 80^\circ

For example,\begin{align*} & \sin\left(\theta+\frac {\pi}  2\right)=\cos \theta\\& \sin\left(\theta-\frac {\pi}  2\right)=-\cos \theta \\& \sin(\pi -\theta)=\sin (\theta)\\&\end{align*}In particular, notice how$$\sin 20^\circ =\sin (80^\circ -60^\circ ) =\sin 80^\circ \cos 60^\circ-\sin 60^\circ\cos 80^\circ $$and $$\sin 100^\circ =\sin (120^\circ - 20^\circ ) =\sin 120^\circ \cos 20^\circ-\sin 20^\circ\cos 120^\circ.$$Now substitute into our original expression:\begin{align*}\sin 20^\circ \sin 40^\circ \sin 60^\circ \sin 80^\circ

direct_answer.text: We were able to simplify using trig identities as follows: \[\begin{aligned} &= \dfrac{1}{2} \cdot \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \cdot [\sin 20^\circ \cos 40^\circ \sin 80^\circ] \\&= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{8} [2 \cdot \sin 20^\circ \cos 40^\circ \sin 80^\circ]. \end{aligned}\] Now applying product-to-sum identity again,\[\begin{aligned} &=\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{8} \Big[ \sin (40^\circ + 20^\circ)-\sin (40^\circ - 20^\circ)\Big]\sin 80^\circ \\ &=\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{8} \Big[ \sin 60^\circ-\sin 20^\circ\Big]\sin 80^\circ \\ &=\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{8} \Big[( \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2})-( \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2})\sin 20^\circ\Big](\sin 80^\circ ). \end{aligned}\]

We know that $(\sin x)(\cos x)=\frac{1}{2}\sin 2x,$ so therefore $$\sin 20^\circ\cdot \sin 80^\circ=2\sin 40^\circ$$ $$2\sin 40^\circ\cdot \sin 100^\circ=2\sin 80^\circ$$ And since sine is symmetrical around $90^\circ$, i.e.,$\sin (180^\circ - x) =\sin x$, it follows that $$\sin 120^\circ\sin 140^\circ = \sin 60^\circ.$$ Thus our desired product simplifies as follows:\begin{align*} & \left[2\sin 40^\circ\right]\left[\sin 60^\circ\right] \left[\sin 80^\circ\right] \\ &= 4 \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \cdot \sin 40^\circ\\ &= 2 \sqrt{3} \sin 40^\circ.\end{align*} Now note furthermore that because \[\cos 40^\circ=\sin (90^\circ

1.subquestion: Express as products of sines or cosines using trigonometric identities.

subanswer.text: Using product-to-sum formulas repeatedly, we have \[\begin{aligned} &\phantom{=}\sin 20^\circ \sin 40^\circ \\ &= -\cos (20^\circ+40^\circ)-\cos (20^\circ-40^\circ)\\ &=\cos 60^\circ-\cos 20^\circ\\ &=\dfrac{1}{2}-\cos 20^\circ,\end{aligned}\][similarly]\[\begin{aligned} &~\sin 60^\circ =\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2},\quad \sin 120^\circ=\sin (60^\circ+60^\circ)=\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\dfrac{1}{2},\\ &~\sin 140^\circ=\sin (120^\circ+20^\circ)=\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\dfrac{1}{2}-\cos 20^\circ,\quad\text{and}\\ &~\sin 160^\circ=\sin (140^\circ+20^\circ)=2\sin 70^\circ \cos 20^\circ.\end{aligned}\] Therefore \[\begin{aligned}\phantom{{\times}}\sin 20^\circ \sin 40^\circ \sin 60^\circ \sin 80^\circ \sin 100^\circ \sin 120^\circ \sin 140^\circ \sin 160^\circ&=(\dfrac{1}{2}-\cos 20^\circ)\sin 80^\circ (\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2})\,(\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\dfrac{1}{2})^{2}\,\\&=(1+\sin 20^\circ)(1-\cos 20^\circ)\sin 80^\circ\,\cot 20^\circ \\&=(1+\sin 20^\circ)(1-\cos 20^\circ)\tan 60^\circ \\ &=\sqrt{3}\,\,(1+\sin 20^\circ)(1-\cos 20^\circ) .\end{aligned}\]

1.subquestion: Express as products of sines or cosines using trigonometric identities.

subanswer.text: Using product-to-sum formulas repeatedly, we have \[\begin{aligned} &\phantom{=}\sin 20^\circ \sin 40^\circ \\ &= -\cos (20^\circ+40^\circ)-\cos (20^\circ-40^\circ)\\ &=\cos 60^\circ-\cos 20^\circ\\ &=\dfrac{1}{2}-\cos 20^\circ,\end{aligned}\][similarly]\[\begin{aligned} &~\sin 60^\circ =\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2},\quad \sin 120^\circ=\sin (60^\circ+60^\circ)=\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\dfrac{1}{2},\\ &~\sin 140^\circ=\sin (120^\circ+20^\circ)=\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\dfrac{1}{2}-\cos 20^\circ,\quad\text{and}\\ &~\sin 160^\circ=\sin (140^\circ+20^\circ)=2\sin 70^\circ \cos 20^\circ.\end{aligned}\] Therefore \[\begin{aligned}\phantom{{\times}}\sin 20^\circ \sin 40^\circ \sin 60^\circ \sin 80^\circ \sin 100^\circ \sin 120^\circ \sin 140^\circ \sin 160^\circ&=(\dfrac{1}{2}-\cos 20^\circ)\sin 80^\circ (\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2})\,(\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\dfrac{1}{2})^{2}\,\\&=(1+\sin 20^\circ)(1-\cos 20^\circ)\sin 80^\circ\,\cot 20^\circ \\&=(1+\sin 20^\circ)(1-\cos 20^\circ)\tan 60^\circ \\ &=\sqrt{3}\,\,(1+\sin 20^\circ)(1-\cos 20^\circ) .\end{aligned}\]

subanswer.text: Using product-to-sum formulas repeatedly, we have \[\begin{aligned} &\phantom{=}\sin 20^\circ \sin 40^\circ \\ &= -\cos (20^\circ+40^\circ)-\cos (20^\circ-40^\circ)\\ &=\cos 60^\circ-\cos 20^\circ\\ &=\dfrac{1}{2}-\cos 20^\circ,\end{aligned}\][similarly]\[\begin{aligned} &~\sin 60^\circ =\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2},\quad \sin 120^\circ=\sin (60^\circ+60^\circ)=\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\dfrac{1}{2},\\ &~\sin 140^\circ=\sin (120^\circ+20^\circ)=\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\dfrac{1}{2}-\cos 20^\circ,\quad\text{and}\\ &~\sin 160^\circ=\sin (140^\circ+20^\circ)=2\sin 70^\circ \cos 20^\circ.\end{aligned}\] Therefore \[\begin{aligned}\phantom{{\times}}\sin 20^\circ \sin 40^\circ \sin 60^\circ \sin 80^\circ \sin 100^\circ \sin 120^\circ \sin 140^\circ \sin 160^\circ&=(\dfrac{1}{2}-\cos 20^\circ)\sin 80^\circ (\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2})\,(\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\dfrac{1}{2})^{2}\,\\&=(1+\sin 20^\circ)(1-\cos 20^\circ)\sin 80^\circ\,\cot 20^\circ \\&=(1+\sin 20^\circ)(1-\cos 20^\circ)\tan 60^\circ \\ &=\sqrt{3}\,\,(1+\sin 20^\circ)(1-\cos 20^\circ) .\end{aligned}\]

2.subquestion: Use double angle formulae to simplify further.

subanswer.text: We know some important trigonometric identities involving sine function such as $$\sin x=2\sin\tfrac12x\cos\tfrac12x.$$ Using this identity repeatedly allows us to cancel out multiple terms while keeping track using parentheses - especially helpful when working with angles like $$(\pi/3),\ (\pi/4),\ (\pi/6)$$ etc., since those fractions convert into multiples very nicely! Here’s how it goes:$$\begin{aligned}&\sin 20^\circ \sin 40^\circ \sin 60^\circ \\ &=(2\sin 10^\circ \cos 10^\circ)(2\sin 20^\circ \cos 20^\circ)\cdot \left[\text{$2\sin(30^{\circ})\cos(30^{\circ})=1}\right]\\ &=\frac{\sin 100^{\circ}}{\sin^2 50^{\circ}}.\end{aligned}$$ Now let’s look again inside square brackets above; notice any similar pattern now emerging here compared earlier steps ? Yes indeed -- more specifically regarding $(\pi/6)$, so next up comes another round trip through our simplification tool

2.subquestion: Use known values for special angles involving multiples of $20^\circ.$

subanswer.text: Let's use multiple angle formulae again:\[\begin{aligned}&\sin 20^\circ=\sin (3\cdot20^\circ)-3\sin^3 20^\circ+3\sin^2 20^\circ\\ &=\sin 60^\circ-\dfrac{3}{4}(1-\cos 40^\circ)+\dfrac{3}{4}(\dfrac{3}{4}-1)=\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\dfrac{3}{4}+\dfrac{9}{16}\\\\&\cos 20^\circ=\cos (3\cdot20^\circ)+3\cos^3 20^\circ-4\cos^2 20^\circ=-4\cos^3 20^\circ+3\cos^2 20^\circ+\cos 20^\circ \\&=\cos 60^\circ+(1-2\sin^2 20^\circ)+(1-\sin^2 20^\circ)\\ &=\dfrac{1}{2}+1-\dfrac{1}{2}-\sin^2 20^\circ+1-\sin^2 20^\circ\\ &=\dfrac{3}{2}-\dfrac{2}{2}\sin^2 20^\circ .\end{aligned}\] Also note that \[\begin{aligned}&~2\sin 70^\circ \cos 20^\circ=\sin (2\cdot70^\circ)=\sin (140^\circ),\\ &~~-2\sin 70^\circ \cos 20^\circ=\sin (140^\circ-(20^\circ))=\sin 120^\circ,\\ &~~~~~~~~2\sin 70^\circ \cos 20^\circ=\sin (2\cdot70^\circ-(20^\circ))=\sin 100^\circ ,\end{aligned}\] so $$\begin{aligned}\phi &=(\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}+\dfrac{1}{2})\left(\dfrac{3}{2}-\dfrac{1}{2}\sin^2 20^\circ\right) \\&=\dfrac{3}{4}+\dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{4}-\dfrac{3}{4}\sin^2 20^\circ.\end{aligned}$$

1.subquestion: Note that $\sin (180^\circ -\theta)=\sin \theta.$ Therefore, which pairs of angles add up to \(180^\circ\) or \(\pi\) radians?

subanswer.text: Pairs include $\{60^\circ, 120^\circ\}$, $\{80^\circ, 100^\circ\}$, $\{40^\circ, 140^\circ\}$. The answer lists three pairs adding to \(180^\circ\).

1.subquestion: Identify common multiple angles whose trigonometric functions may have readily available exact forms (in terms of radical expressions), within the specified range up till \(60^\circ\) considering their relationship such as supplemental, complimentary etc., also knowing at least some simple triangle properties where applicable.

subanswer.text: There exist numerous pairs fulfilling our criteria among which includes but not limited to {(20°),(30°)},{(40°), (50°)} based upon complements amongst other possibilities. Notably, certain notable ones include; \(\sin(20^\circ)\) being part of sin(\((1/2)\pi\)-\(20^\circ\))=sin(\(π/6\)+40º)=cos(40º), while \(\sin(50^\circ)\) equates cosine half its measure i.e.; cos(25º); similarly,\(\sin(40^\circ)\) matches with cosine double of itself e.g.; cos(80º). Likewise applying Pythagorean identities yields corresponding cotangent counterparts too thereby facilitating quicker computations using well established right angled trinomials' squares root extraction methods leading towards simplified square roots expression formulations through simplification efforts albeit requiring more extensive working space due consideration factor of 'rounding off errors'.
